cases.title: People-pleasing / Hard to say no
cases.oneLiner: You often agree to avoid conflict, then feel stressed or resentful.
signals: You say yes quickly, then regret it.
You avoid asking for what you need.
You worry others will be disappointed.

questions.text: I agree to requests even when I don't have time.
I feel anxious when I might disappoint someone.
After saying yes, I feel resentful or exhausted.
I avoid giving honest feedback to keep the peace.

exampleTemplates.title: Work/School boundary
exampleTemplates.text: When [person] asks you to take on [task] last-minute, say: “I can’t do it today. I can do [smaller part] by [time], or we can schedule it for [date].”

exampleTemplates.title: Family request
exampleTemplates.text: If [family member] wants you to do [favor], reply: “I can help for [30 minutes] on [day]. If you need more, let’s plan together.”

exampleTemplates.title: Friend invitation
exampleTemplates.text: When a friend invites you to [event] but you’re tired, say: “I’m going to rest tonight. Can we do [shorter option] on [other day]?”

howToPullFromLife: List 3 situations this month where you said “yes” too fast.
For each, write: who asked, what they asked, your real capacity (time/energy).
Pick one situation and rewrite a 1-sentence boundary using the templates.

cases.title: Perfectionism / Over-polishing
cases.oneLiner: You delay finishing because it must be “perfect”, which costs time and energy.
signals: You fear being judged for mistakes.

questions.text: I spend too long polishing details that others barely notice.
I hesitate to start because I’m not sure I can do it perfectly.
I feel bad when my work is 'good' but not 'excellent'.
I avoid sharing drafts because they aren’t ready.

exampleTemplates.title: Define 'good enough'
exampleTemplates.text: Before starting [task], define a 70% version: “Success means [3 bullet criteria]. Anything beyond that is optional.”

exampleTemplates.title: Timebox polishing
exampleTemplates.text: Set a timer for [25 minutes] to polish [section]. When it ends, ship it or ask for feedback.

exampleTemplates.title: Draft-first communication
exampleTemplates.text: Send a draft to [person] with a label: “Rough draft — I want feedback on [2 questions], not grammar.”

howToPullFromLife: Choose one task you keep delaying.
Write what 'failure' looks like in your head; then write what is actually acceptable.
Pick a timebox (15–45 min) and decide what you will deliver at the end.

cases.title: Avoidance / Hard conversations
cases.oneLiner: You postpone uncomfortable conversations, so small issues grow bigger.
signals: You 'wait for the right time' that never comes.
You replay conversations in your head.
You feel relief when you avoid it, then more anxiety later.

questions.text: I delay addressing issues because I fear conflict.
I hope problems resolve on their own instead of talking.
I overthink what to say and never start.
After avoiding, the issue becomes harder to handle.

exampleTemplates.title: 2-minute opener
exampleTemplates.text: Open with: “Can we talk for 5 minutes about [topic]? My goal is [goal], not blaming.”

exampleTemplates.title: Observation → Impact → Request
exampleTemplates.text: Say: “When [specific behavior], I feel [emotion] because [impact]. Can we try [request]?”

exampleTemplates.title: Schedule it instead of forcing now
exampleTemplates.text: If timing is bad: “I want to discuss [topic]. When is a good time today or tomorrow?”

howToPullFromLife: Write the 1-sentence issue: “We need to talk about ____.”
Write your goal (what you want after the talk).
Pick one template and fill in blanks with names and one concrete example.
